description.text:
This is a small pressure equalization valve. It's used to maintain air pressure between two drying chambers. It's made of NYLON as NYLON provides a single part permanent hinged flap as a part of NYLON's flexibility.
For more info on printing in NYLON see:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Combination-CNC-Machine-and-3D-Printer/

This part is designed for standard 1/2" ID hose. Made of just three parts, all of NYLON, it's a simple assembly.
Perimeters = 2
Fill = 50% ends and 20% flap
Print, assemble, connect.
You should mark the direction of airflow during assembly as it's not obvious from the outside.

title: UV Curing Station Cover and Instructions

description.text:
I wanted to create a unique lid for a UV Resin print curing station for my new Phrozen Make resin printer due here next month. I print small pieces, so I didn't need much by way of size, so this is re-sized to 180mm in diameter and 180mm tall, which will fit nicely over the UV-powered rotating stand. I used the "Furo Oke" bath pail by Tomonori (Arigato!) as a starting point and added a hole in the bottom for the UV light strip plug. I am still printing this out as I put this up, so I will update it when finished. I will, however, post links to all the parts you need. I am printing this (initially) in Vase-mode, just to save time. Unsure how strong it will be. ***NOTE: I also dropped the model about 11mm below the bed so I didn't have to worry about supports for the "lip".

Now, for the build. You will need the following or similar (all prices in US $ and US voltages):

UV Light Strip - $15.99 -
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01L7JEAN0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

12v Power Supply - $7.99 -
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B019Q3U72M/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Decorative Mirror Tiles - $9.99 - (you can likely get smaller/cheaper package, I like overkill)
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01AAGGHO6/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o08_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Solar-Powered Display Stand - $5.99 - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002Y2AW3C/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o09_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

That's less than $40!

So, print-out this thing, then line the inside walls with the mirror tiles. You could also save money and just use aluminum foil and some hot glue, but make sure it's as smooth as possible. That would save you a few bucks right there!

Now, insert the power lead through the hole in the cover from the inside, then start peeling the adhesive backing off of the light strip and start wrapping it along the inside, leaving a space of about 1/4" as you spiral it around until you get to the lip of the cover. Now, I have a pretty lengthy strip here (I WAS going to just use a cheap 5-gallon bucket, but where the heck is the fun in that?), so you can probably do just fine with a half-sized strip! Look, more money saved!

Once you have everything secured nicely, just plug in the light strip, and you have a serious little UV curing set-up, albeit for small prints. If you have a need for one for bigger stuff that won't fit, you can take the same principles and do it with a 5 gal bucket, or even a box, be creative! I have no idea of the proper timing for this, but I would say no more than a few minutes to start with for testing.

As you can see from the pics, I stopped the model print early because I decided that it was big enough for my needs. It was a fast and ugly print, and there are thin/open areas that let the UV light through. My final will be MUCH nicer...

Enjoy!

Curt Pangracs

A mechanical not gate using input and output rods. The problem with rods is when you start chaining them together you would need more and more force to operate the circuit. I guess this could be called a clocked gate? It only operates when the plunger at the bottom is pushed up. Possibly by a cam. The next row of gates would need to be delayed.. so another cam with later timing.  
I have only just come up with the idea now, So will need to flesh it out. Im thinking a modular system...

This seems overly complicated for a simple "tested" not gate - (more sliding and rotating points than necessary).
You might be interesting in this kind of reversible rod-logic:
http://www.zyvex.com/nanotech/mechano.html

description.text: A simple design to attach your power supply and solid state relay to the underside of your Mendelmax.

The threaded hole spacing on the underside of my power supply was 50mm by 150mm, so the "Power_Supply_Carriage.stl" has holes spaced to allow positioning the power supply either parallel to your Y-axis or perpendicular to it. If mounted parallel to the Y-axis you will have extra space for the relay. "Power_Supply_Carriage_Solid.stl" is also provided if you would like to drill out a different arrangement of holes. IMPORTANT NOTES:
1) You will need some kind of feet on your printer to use these, this design requires ~35mm of clearance underneath the printer. 2) My power supply is only 50mm tall. It is mounted near the motor and clears the Y-axis belt by only 2 or 3 mm. If you're using Y-axis parts other than MendelMax 1.5 the belt might not clear the power supply. 3) This carriage spans 260mm, that means that you will need a print area at least 200 X 200 mm and have to print it diagonally. You may be able to print two to a plate if you have a larger print area. I printed them one at a time. 4) Print two of one file, not both files. Only use "Power_Supply_Carriage_Solid.stl" if you intend to drill your own holes.

Two different concave footpads for the Onewheel+. They are the same shape, but one is shallower than the other. The idea was to recreate the area of a skateboard deck where the concave transitions to the tail. If you put your foot straight across, it is cradled nicely in the dip. You can play with how you angle your foot to change how it engages with the rise at the toe and heel. The deep one might feel a bit exteme so I recommend starting with the shallow one.

Use #10-32 heat inserts (https://www.mcmaster.com/#93365a154/=18m936m) to capture the front screws. These will fit a Onewheel V1 with the addition of OW+ bumpers.

comments.text: I did actually sink the gem into the crown slightly for a good connection, but the surface area was still really low at The connection point.  I printed at .1 mm layer height For Extra bonding but it was fragile until I gave it a once over with acetone to seal the bond. I may have just gotten lucky.  I printed it with support and it printed, but you break off almost all the fragile bits while removing support, including the gem. I think the radius was either 5 or 10 cm, I'm not sure. If you can create a comb, definitely post it. I'll try to export the gem separately tomorrow.  The gem less version is actually meant to make a "real" jewelry version by setting a 1 maximum marquise cut topaz or aquamarine into a metal printed or cast crown which is why I didn't export the gem originally.  Thanks for the feedback!

title: Monoprice MP Select Mini V2 40mm Fan Shroud

description.text:
This is a replacement for the fan shroud that comes mounted to the hot end of Monoprice Select Mini printers. This new shroud supplies the printed parts and heat break with superior cooling and allows for the mounting of a 40mm fan.

This model was designed to work with m4 bolts which means that whatever 40mm fan you have should have 4mm diameter screw holes in it. I have attached a stl file with a 3D printable bolt in case you do not own one of the correct length.

The clearance between the bottom of this shroud and the print bed/printed part is about 1mm. Thanks to the super simple and repeatable mounting of this shroud, this value should be fairly consistent for everyone who uses the model.

This shroud is even easier to mount than the stock shroud that comes on the printer. While the model still uses the same retaining springs, the tabs are a little bit easier to get the spring around and the flat piece at the top of the model forces the assembly to stay in place after the first spring is attached.

This design is still a work in progress and as such, comments about possible improvements and any questions you may have are welcome.

description.text: The gauge dimension is 127mm is what we use in Western Australia

A remix of a temperature calibration tower.
Added 10 mm to base for a warmer start to stick to the bed. Also added the temperature changes so you don't have to.

Using the dot stl file create gcode for dot then replace the layer code with Self Temp Tower Layer Code.

When slicing dot use 210 extruder temperature.

Instructions:
1: Download files
2: Slice dot .stl and save to gcode file. (When slicing dot use 210 extruder temperature.)
3: Open Self Temp Tower Layer Code.gcode in notepad
4: Select all and Copy to clipboard
5: Open dot gcode in notepad
6: Select layer code. (Starts with ";Layer count: XX") Ends at the beginning of your end code.
7 Paist from clipboard.
8: Save changes
Done

Here is the base I use to keep them organized.

title: Cable chain brackets for Printrbot+ Classic

description.text: Printed parts to use 10x15mm cable chain with the Printrbot+

Part 1 mounts by the extruder motor, Part 2 mounts next to the X-axis motor, and Part 3 mounts near the Z-axis endstop access hole.  
One meter of 10x15mm cable chain should suffice.  Longer 6-32 machine screws are necessary.

description.text:
This 10 Gallon Filter Hanger can be utilized in conjunction with my Hanger System (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2448292) to hold a 10 Gallon Filter on the inside of a tank that would normally be setup as a HOB (hang on back) filter.

WARNING
Please be aware hanging a filter on the inside of a tank that is normally setup to be outside the tank exposes wiring and connections to water and creature interaction on the inside. I've taken extra precautions to make sure my setup is safe and I can't recommend it without experience disassembling / sealing filter components.
WARNING

description.text:
After seeing the Onix and Geodude featured here on Thingiverse by user ClassyGoat a little bit ago we decided to make another popular Pokemon 3d printer ready! Vaporeon! This print is going to need to be printed WITH supports! Based on the 3d Pokemon Models Project at
http://roestudios.co.uk/project/3d-pokemon-models/ Pokemon Copyright Gamefreak/Nintendo Edited for printing by: Nate L.
Using Blender If there are other Pokemon from the site you would like to be made 3d printer ready please leave your suggestions in the comments!

This model has to be printed with supports!   
The stack in front of the head is to ensure better print quality at the end of the print where the tip of the fin on Vaporeon's head gets very tiny.  
This model should be fine to print at .3mm layer height or lower.  
Have fun while printing!

description.text:
What is it?

Modular and stack-able basic support stick for plants. That means: the taller your plant grows, the more you simply print and put together.

What is the reason for it?

  • Length should be adjusted for plant height

  • As simple, easy and fast to print as possible

  • Mechanism to fix plant loosely to the stick

Why this and not others?

Simply saying, I was not able to find something like this, which fit my needs in an acceptable way. Only partly reasonable solution I found was that: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1677408. However it was pretty big and felt it was "too much". Other solutions like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:352015 or https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:845519 required, that I own sticks. Well I do not.

What is the solution then?

Summing up in short:

  • Printing time: ~1hr (with Flashforge Creator Pro)

  • Material usage: ~14g

  • Total length: 220mm (smaller print volume may require printing in diagonal, or scaling down a bit)

  • Sticks can be stacked easily, where smaller plants may require 1 stick, taller plants maybe 2-3 sticks

  • 7 holes, each diameter 2.5mm for binding of the plant. (When buying electronics you always have those tiny black/white binders holding the cables together, they fit perfectly through those holes. You can also consider to print a small hook, that fits inside, if you want to keep this as a 100% printable solution)

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

I suggest to print with small supports to improve quality of male/female connector parts for later connection, especially male part needs support.
Removal of support material for female part may be tricky. For me a small screwdriver was fine to "stab" it inside and loosen the support material. Then pulling it out was easy.

title: Automatic shut down after print - Arret automatique alim imprimante

description.text:
en francais en fin de description ----------------------------------------------------------------------

I use to print by night
I wanted an automatic shutdown of my printer at the end of work

I fix a new en stop on the front face of the bed
This end stop cuts the power supply of a relay
This relay cuts the power supply of the all printer ...

you just need to add in the end-Gcode in Cura : "G1 Y200"

Useful, easy and fun !

Beware off the 220 voltage for you and your printer
Don't forget to have a look to your printer when printing ....

j'imprime beaucoup de nuit
je voulais que l'alimentation de mon imprimante s’arrête en fin d'impression.
j'ai ajouté un fin de course en butée Y max
ce fin de course déclenche un relais sur le 220 volts de l'alimentation

il suffit donc que j'ajoute au code de fin d'impression (end-Gcode) dans Cura un déplacement en Y200 (G1 Y200) pour que le plateau se déplace au bout et attaque le fin de course et arrête l'imprimante.

le petit schéma joint permet d'y voir plus clair
il faut ajouter un interrupteur ou un bouton poussoir pour armer ou bypasser le relais

c'est pratique, facile et fun !

attention :
le 220 volts, c'est dangereux pour l'homme et l'imprimante !
un arrêt automatique ne supprime pas votre surveillance de l'imprimante pendant l'impression

relais à utiliser
https://www.amazon.fr/Info-Games-RELAIS-STANDARD-JZC-22F/dp/B00L3IDAJQ/ref=sr_1_5?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1500802887&sr=1-5&keywords=relais+24v

fin de course à utiliser
https://www.amazon.fr/Micro-interrupteur-Course-CQC-Inverseur-rouleau/dp/B00Q5UV0TO/ref=sr_1_11?s=electronics&ie=UTF8&qid=1500802939&sr=1-11&keywords=fin+de+course

title: Targaryen Dragon Symbol from Game of Thrones
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was a quick 20m job in openscad, importing a House Targaryen symbol and making it into a plaque.

Wanted to try out the colour swapping based on layer on my Prusa i3 MK2S and this seemed like a good idea. Really loved how it turned out, but had to print 2, on the first one got the layer change wrong and it printed the first layer of red on top of the black so I didn't get the contrast I wanted.

I've included the STL for the thing, it's big because I used a high res image and I wanted to print it big, the one in the picture is 146mm diameter.
I've also included the gcode I used to print it, should work on a Original Prusa i3 Mk2S using PLA, of course you can use the STL to slice however you want, but the gcode already includes the M600 for layer change at the right place :) and the black portion is optimized to print at 0.25mm and then switches to 0.1mm for the Dragons detail.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.05-0.25mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Should be an easy print with the gcode supplied it took me 8hrs. Smaller and bigger slices will make it faster.
Regular cleanup mostly some stringy bits if you want to avoid strings increase your retraction or lower the temperature a bit.
Openscad using a image to define a surface object.

description.text:
Remix of the excelent Lack Raiser for 3d Printer enclosure, with plexiglass windows. I added some hinges for the door.

Raisers are printed in very low quality. For the hinges I used 0.2 mm layer height and 30% infill.

Remember to print hinge_part_2 and filament_guide and lock_slot upside down (rotate 180 degrees)

Also, lock_bottom was printed on the side, printing such an overhang with support proved to be a challenge.. Printing it on the side with support ONLY on the heated bed did the trick.

Yet another anti wobble Z-axis holder for 8mm flanged lead screw nuts. It is made to fit a Geeetech I3 Pro B printer.

Unlike other designs I have seen this one does not require any screws. It has protruding cylinders that fits into the holes on the nut to hold it in place. This reduces its height enough that if you lower the motors you will not need to raise the print bed.

author: DexterBrown

description.text: This is a bracket to hold small brushless motors. It affixes motors to the 5mm thick photocard commonly used to build foam-flyer radio controlled aircraft.

Print the model (I used an Ultimaker and PLA). Then tidy up holes to match your screws, nuts, bolts etc. Remove any stringing with a sharp knife. Sand off any sharp edges to avoid damaging wiring and improve safety.
Fit the motor to the bracket first. (I used a CF2805 motor but this should work with a range of small RC brushless motors)
The bracket will push firmly onto the edge of 5mm standard paper covered photoboard as available in the UK from most art shops. Use glue and dowells to permanently fix the bracket to the board.

author: CPLK

title: Union Station HO Scale - ala Walthers style
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update: Have added a few interior details - ticketing booths, bench seats in the waiting area, and a couple of snack vending machines. Also added some roof vents to the roof.
Attribution to raleon for the 2 vending machines.

Your support can help me to create and release more new designs.
Become a Patron!
Thank you.

HO scale Union Station train station.
This is in the style of the kit available from Walthers.
It is 19-3/4 x 8-1/4 x 7 inches.
At the moment it does not have any interior details. I am working on this.
I recommend running the stl's through netfabb before printing.
You need to print the following files multiple times:
lg-front-window - x 12
lg-window - x 16
sm-window - x 16
frnt-dbl-door - x5
roller-door - x5
skylight - x5
pillar - x6
fancy-skylight - x 2
bench-seat-bottom - x 12
bench-seat-top - x 12
Ticket-booth-window - x 6
ticket-booth-door - x 6
roof-vent - x 8

Assembly notes:

With the main building, assemble the front wall, assemble the rear wall. Attach the two side walls to the front only, then insert the roof (it slides in from the rear in slots), THEN attach the rear wall.
All windows, doors and skylights will require clear plastic for glass.

My navigation device is quite old (and so is its holder), so perhaps nobody does have the exact same model. Maybe someone can use this and remix it to fit his connector, so i uploaded it nevertheless.

If you came across searching for a holder for your Moto G you may want to have a look at this existing one:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:469483
I did not use for my holder design, but i believe it is designed for the most common connector.

author: s589521678

description.text: This is a pleasant turtle to have by your side as a faithful companion. The second version allows you to put him/her on a pencil. Made using Tinkercad. This is like a version 2 of my other turtle, but this is much bigger, thanks to a better slicing engine on Makerbot's part from the time I made the other one. This model is remarkably durable and can withstand some drops but not all, especially to the feet but the eyes are more stable than the last model. This works best as a test for most printers to see how well it can slice and print, or as a sort of "hello world" (although more like hello turtle). Does require supports.

I used PLA Plastic in green for mine, but you can have any color you want. To use pencil topper function, put the pencil between the feet, facing the turtle's head. for thicker pencils and some pens use the other side. The secondary model is designed specifically for a standard pencil, and although very loose, it works. For bigger pencils, you can scale the turtle. It can withstand small drops but bigger drops can damage the feet and/or eyes. Print with supports.

remixed_from.author: thecrazy
remixed_from.title: Calliper brackets for high precision printer calibration

title: Prusa Mendel Caliper Clamps for Calibration

description.text:
Based on the wonderful work of "thecrazy", I have created my own set of caliper clamps in order to better calibrate my Mendel. Please excuse my messy, over-extruded parts. Photos loosely follow steps listed under instructions. Requires: 10 M3 Nuts to join halves and for bar clamp
2 M3 3.8mm heatset inserts (or 2 more M3 nuts) for filament holder
8 M3 x 16mm Screws to join front and back halves around calipers
4 M3 x 10mm Screws for bar clamp and filament holder
10 M3 washers are probably optional

1) Print out bar calmp, back half, filament holder, and 2 of the front half parts. Print out the "filamentholderNUT" file if using M3 nuts instead of heatset inserts.   
2) Insert nuts and/or heatseat inserts. A soldering iron works great for setting nuts in your parts.   
3) Attach front and back halves around your caliper jaws   
4) Attach clamp to frame member in front of Y-Axis.   
5) Home Y-Axis and Zero Calipers, then jog Y-Axis 100mm. Repeat, average results, and make firmware changes if necessary.   
6) Move to the X-Axis by attaching your clamp to your Z-Axis smooth rod, making sure that the carriage will make adequate contact and that nothing interferes.  
7) Just like the Y-Axis, Home your X-Axis, extend your calipers until they touch the carriage, zero the calipers, and then jog your X-Axis 100mm. Repeat, adjust, repeat, etc.  
8) On to the Z-Axis... Attach your clamps above your extruder as shown and measure just like you did the Y and X.   
9) Add your filament holder and remaining "front half" pieces to your front caliper jaws. Align your calipers and X-Axis so that the filament will be fed as straight as possible.   
10) Feed filament through the filament holder and into your extruder. Close your calipers as far as possible and clamp the filament in place using the set screws. Extrude 1 or 2mm of filament to remove any slack.  
11) Zero your calipers and extrude filament in 10mm increments. As you can see, I was over-extruding by almost 10%...  
12) Repeat anal-retentive calibration process until you exceed the precision of your calipers.

author: pirinonew

title: ImpulseRC Alien 5" RGB ws2812b rear bumper with 45° antenna mount for Unify pro

description.text:
Its a rear bumper for the ImpulseRC Alien frame.

Please use Flex filament. PLA or ABS aint no good for this part.

It holds the antenna socket from a Unify PRO 5V or HV in a 45° angle.
That means you can use the short version of a TBS Triumph to compensate the extra weight of the printed bumper.
Its designed to hold 3 of these WS2812B RGB LEDs which can be controlled by KISS FC version 1.2 or higher or any Betaflight compatible FC.
http://www.ebay.de/itm/New-WS2812B-4-5V-5050-RGB-LED-Lamp-Panel-Board-4-Bit-Precise-For-Arduino-/272482002329?hash=item3f71316599:g:7-8AAOSw6DtYTRrq

Use some nylon screws and nylon nuts to screw the LED-boards on the bumper.
Please do not use metal screws or you will short out the LEDs.
You can fill the caps with epoxy to make it even more crash resistance.

Use a very sharp knife to get rid of the support material.
Its a pain to clean this up so take your time.

If you like this design please check out my youtube channel and give me a like or two ;)
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UChTMnYrYm60CbVZFyUXTwSg?view_as=subscriber

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm

10-20%

Notes:

Successfull printed with a Ultimaker 2+

PLEASE DO A QUICK TESTPRINT WITH YOUR PRINTER IF YOU ARE NOT USING A ULTIMAKER 2+. Things will come out smaller or bigger on other printers.

Print in TPA with 20% Fill and 6mm Wall Thickness.
Use a fine nozzle to save weight.
Mine is about 4gr. If you use a 0.1mm nozzle you can bring this down to 4gramm.

Remix of Anet A8 PSU Cover, with mounting holes for multiple 30A PSU:s. Since the mounting holes do move around from PSU to PSU and some holes missing on some models. I added 4 holes to so least 2 of 4 align. Also added some more space on both back corners for cable routing and a hole for a Led light switch.

Here is the connector Im using: hhttps://www.aliexpress.com/item/3D-Printer-Parts-i4-Parts-Power-supply-switch-Adapter-XD-110-C/32834223938.html

And the mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2423368

The PSU in the picture: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/High-Quality-30A-360W-adapter-12v-switching-power-supply-adapter-led-strip-SM5050-SMD3528-SMD5630-light/2017743397.html

3 of the 4 holes align on this model which makes it nice and tight, the swivel idea from the original model works still by removing just one screw. So you still get fast access to the cables if needed, but its a tad more secure since it does not swivel when locked in place with the third screw.

The switch for the led lights: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Super-12V-20A-Blue-LED-Light-OFF-ON-SPST-Toggle-Rocker-Switch-For-Car-Sales-170228/32794834204.html

remixed_from.author: Reflector
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 Offset Fan Direct Cooling Duct ("The Magnum")

description.text:
Update: Centrifugal Blower Supermagnum variant and adapter (Which will fit the axial (This version) if you are trying to convert over but are willing to lose some airflow. Otherwise go print the centrifugal version of the duct) over here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2452863

An improved version of The Magnum.
May contain peanuts and/or be processed on machinery that handles nuts as well as:

  1. Significantly enlarged ports, easily double over the unreleased proto-Supermagnum and quadruple of The Magnum.
  2. Ports are angled at closer to a 30 degree slope, which is easier to print.
  3. Ring of slightly larger diameter to maintain distance from the heater block
  4. Port length elongated
  5. Ports are aimed slightly more downwards to direct airflow towards the surface of the object as well.
  6. Bridging assist feature angle changed to 45 degrees. A little messier, but more space if you're using a fan with a smaller hub, if you have one.

Doesn't contain:

  1. Heavy sarcasm
  2. A brand new design
  3. (As of publishing, this will be corrected by the time most people read this) Photo of the actual printed one because the sun is rising outside and my brain is dead.
  4. A logical, reasonable sequence of photos, because sun outside window/etc. You should see the unpublished proto Supermagnum prototype in comparison as well as that compared to The Magnum.

Go ahead, place your finger under (a hopefully cool) nozzle. Or in front of one of the ports. You can feel the flow, even from the stock fan.

I may release a further update which has a bridging assist for the ports, but I recommend rotating your layers so that it does not attempt to align the bridging layer parallel to the port. Just a 15 degree offset should do.

I may or may not consider making an air inducement variant of a direct cooling system to gain more volume, but I have this suspicion that higher pressure wins out. There most likely will be a 40mm centrifugal version of the SuperMagnum in the near future. It will most likely be a redesign to use space efficiently. If not a simple, a stupid adapter bracket that allows the existing SuperMagnum and Magnum to be interfaced with a centrifugal will come out first.

Also you're still going to want that fan standoff. See The Magnum if you want to print this but don't know why it includes a second part and cannot determine the reason without raising a hand for adult assistance.

A warning: You will lose a little bit of print area in the left corner (Perspective: You facing the printer) if you use these ducts, they will bump the motor. They effectively take about 1 inch/2-3cm, as in the legs of a triangle more or less. Obviously you have more to lose if you stick anything like a heatsink onto your steppers.

title: Wanhao Duplicator 6 Offset Fan Air Inducement Duct

description.text:
If you liked my air inducement duct, I forgot to release this version of it which has the same offset fan configuration as my later designs. I went with direct cooling for the intense amount of directed airflow in those later designs and I have been sticking with that. This is just something that I didn't release since I made that jump.

For anyone confused about the offset fan: Imagine if I put a shopping bag with a tiny hole at the top of your hair and asked you if you liked breathing more or a compact fan and air duct configuration more Somewhere I should add that I start pouring water over your head, but that's a metaphor for hot plastic. I promise, there won't be a wet towel over that plastic bag in that process. I'm more than sure that fan doesn't like being there with the lack of clearance. You could also read all the other summaries on my later air duct designs.

You may or may not see a comeback for these designs, possibly with some direct cooling designs that use air entrainment on the nozzles to deliver a greater volume of air at reduced velocity and pressure. Otherwise the other option is to have a tighter ring and most likely a centrifugal blower to create a compact air column around the nozzle.

Ugly prototype and uglier lazy photo included so you know that I actually do make and test these things before I publish them instead insulting your intelligence by going "trust me, just test this and let me know if I should silently delete this and pretend this failure never happened" all while lazily pumping out designs in CAD for some kind of weak mental brownie points thing.

Also I forgot if I used my 14mm or 13mm standoff, so have fun with both files. If you don't know what they're for and can't figure it out, look at my other duct "The Magnum" for an image of how they're mounted. If the 13mm is too short, just start a print for another one and stop it as its printing the first few layers (Depending on how thick it is.) If the 14mm is too tall, I hope you enjoy sanding (a lot).

A warning: You will lose a little bit of print area in the left corner (Perspective: You facing the printer) if you use these ducts, they will bump the motor. They effectively take about 1 inch/2-3cm, as in the legs of a triangle more or less. Obviously you have more to lose if you stick anything like a heatsink onto your steppers.

description.text:
Visit https://www.instructables.com/id/Portable-Wind-Generator-As-a-Cell-Phone-Charger/ for full information

In India, there are lots of people who still prefer trains to travel and spend days together to complete their journey. Most trains usually don't provide electricity even though there are charging sockets available. Even if they do, it is seen that such a charging facility takes a longer time than usual to fully charge the cell phone. Sometimes the passengers can even be seen fighting for charging their cell phones if there are less number of charging sockets available. I've myself witnessed people waiting at every coach's doors to get a chance to charge their phones.

To this problem, a common temporary solution may be a to use a typical PowerBank which doesn't last longer and need to be charged again. Solar cells are next preferred ones but are unreliable at most times and they are not economical too. So my unique solution to this problem is to use a Wind Generator. Since the trains run at least for 20 hours a day with a minimum speed of 30kmph, the wind hitting the windows can be converted into valuable electrical energy and hence charge our cell phones.

The application of this 5 watt wind generator is not just limited to a moving train but is immense as it can easily be used while travelling on any vehicle like bicycles, buses, motorbikes,recreational vehicles..etc.

In this simple Instructible I'll show you how to make one for yourself with the easiest method possible.

https://www.instructables.com/id/Portable-Wind-Generator-As-a-Cell-Phone-Charger/
I found some parts through thingiverse, modified and assembled them all into one. I used the software blender to do so.

comments.text: Posted pictures of what Im using part number 5225K711 from Mcmastercarr. If you wanted to use a different size filiment you have to use a different type fitting because this is for 4mm tubes. I still prefer your design over serges. Its just seems like the LM8UU bearings will shift at some point in his design. Also I found a trick to put more flex in the PLA even at those thin sections is to use a torch and just graze the plastic. It melts the top layer to make it one solid piece of plastic and alows the PLA to flex alot more before snapping.
comments.author: chevydan6

comments.text: That's excellent.  I had noticed that Serge was putting an M5 nut around the tube to hold it, but this is a great idea, although it does require getting the fitting.  Would it be useful to embed the fitting directly into this?  Another thought i had was to remove the bearing mount (I actually tested this and it is very useful) and replace it with a plate similar to Serge's.  Effectively, each plate would be shaped differently to hold different bearings and so allow for different filament sizes.  This is what I did with my second machine (see some comments I put out).  Which fitting are you using (and where did you get it)?  Another thing to consider with this as I am printing in ABS: the weakness of this design is the that the bearings are built upwards which means that when you shove the bearings in there, the plastic may give along the horizontal if the material has no flex.  To get around this, I slathered my bearings in the liquid, runny superglue and let it cure which gave it all the strength needed to withstand my abuse.  Ultimately, in my second printer, I reverted to Serge's design for one simple reason, I solved the issue with the slop in the LM8UUs by putting some blue tape (the painter's tape you can get anywhere), twice around each bearing, which effectively deprecated my design.  In my first printed, I actually used pillow block LM8UUs which bold directly onto the plate and while heavier, pose no issue for this printer or motors.  I like that because they are totally modular, bolt on and allow some amount of adjustment in place.  At some point, I hope to convince Serge to do this across the board.  I am working on a CNC machined version of some of these parts because I like the idea of all metal components for rigidity, but that means upgrades can't be printed, which defeats the idea behind the SmartRap.  Anyway, those are my thoughts.  Feel free to discuss more ideas here or directly offline.

title: Flower Windmill
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Here we have our Flower Windmill. We have been working on the design for a number of weeks now and it is finally ready for you all to download and print your own. Please be sure to share the pictures of your finished flowers spinning away in your garden.

If you like what we do then please do follow us on Thingiverse and social media as we have lots more to share with you in the coming months.

All our windmills were printed using our very own Pongo Filaments, and all are available at www.pongostore.com

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Supports only needed on the stem parts and only supports on the bed, not everywhere.all other parts should print fine without supports or a raft, though we like to use rafts for ease of removal and guaranteed perfect first layer.

Please note that orientation of the petals on the bed will affect how flexible they are based on your chosen resolution. The petals are 0.6mm thick so at 0.2 you will have 3 layers and depending on what software and machine you are using will depend on what direction the layers are printed and this affects the rigidity on the finished print.

Please do share your printed windmills with us, we would love to see what colour you print yours in.

If your printer has good accuracy you should find that most parts fit together really snug, however due to the pressure on the central petal joint assembly you may find that you need to glue these together once you have your petals in place.

If you are having any issues with your assembly then please do get in touch with us we would be happy to answer any question.

description.text:
There are lots of fairly neat filament cleaners out there, but I put this together to fior my old RepRapPro (which is still doing great service!). Apart from the printed parts, you only need two 16mm M3 cap screws and two M3 nuts.

I've used the cleaner in a dry state, but there is a hole to allow you to moisten the sponge with a little mineral oil.

Printer:

RepRapPro Mendel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

35%

Notes:

This was printed in PETG which I usually print with a bit more than standard infil. With parts of this size though, it doesn't make much difference.

The cap is a fairly close fit and is held in place by its own pressure.

It just needs to be assembled and positioned in front of the extruder. Just add a small piece of sponge with a slit in the middle - the sponge should not be too big as it should only wipe the filament, not squeeze it. After that, you're good to go.

Don't worry about the red and black... I was just running out of red so I pressed on pause changed for black and resumed. 2 functions for that compass...
first: Make circles, like any compass. second: Reproduce irregular shapes like a rock. If you need to fit a piece of wood tight close to it. If it is horizontal or vertical, you can even help the process with a torpille bubble level. Look at 2 images and the video. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JSm0pXgfxlo

I added to the design brims at the ends of the main piece because it was shrinking a lot on my printer. Don't worry, it is easy to remove with a knife.  
You will also need a ~1 1/2 inch wood screw, and a set of bolt and nut 8-32 (1 1/4)  
You may have to enlarge the hole to fit the wood screw with a drill.  
You may have to use a knife to remove a very little bit of plastic on the smallest side of the pencil pusher to fit it really tight. once in its place it will not fall again.  
You can glue the bolt in it's place or you can heatup the bolt and make it stick in the molten plastic.  
It works better with those carpenter flat pencil but it works with any pen pencil marker or chalk.  
I designed it for my work (carpenter), but every kid that come home go with my compass and I have to print myself a new one!  
If you need bigger circles. You can print only the slider, and use a piece of wood instead of the main piece.

title: Dell A870P Power Supply to Bench Supply Cover

description.text:
I needed a 12V bench supply so I converted a Dell A870P Server PSU. This cover snaps over the end of the PSU (Commonly used in the R710). It includes slots for you to place pieces of copper clad PCB to mate with the connectors on the power supply, or you can just solder directly to the plates on the PSU.

The design includes holes for 4 banana posts, a switch and a LED.

To turn the power supply on, you'll need to short the bottom and third from the bottom pins all the way on the right hand side to ground.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20

Notes:

Print with the face down to the build plate, you'll want to add supports underneath the slots for the copper plates (if you're going to use them)

Remote all supports, and with cut small (20mm x 8mm) pieces of copper clad PCB and solder leads to them, push them into the slots be sure that they are flush. Connect leads to the banana posts, and either short the pins noted above or attach your switch.

Slowly insert the cap onto the end of the PSU, apply power and you're good to go!

description.text:
After printing we all have to store our filament properly. One part is to ensure that the it does not unwind from the spoole.
I did this by threading the filament into the hole(s) on the edge of the spool what also means to loos 5 to 15 cm of filament each time I store it. And I did not like that and came up with this little tool. The part with the hole comes over the end of the thread, the other part could be clamped to the next thread / winding. By moving the tool everything tigthens up.

I'm pretty sure that I'm not the first on with this kind of solution but I'm new to every thing (fusion 360, slic3r, 3d printing etc.) I like to practice ;-)

title: Case for OLED screen + Wemos D1 mini ESP8266

description.text:
This is a small case for an OLED screen and a Wemos D1 Mini ESP8266 Wifi module.

OLED screen is connected on I2C bus, driven by a SSD1306 controller and has a resolution of 128x64 pixels (96 inches).

Wemos D1 mini ESP8266 module drives the screen and connects to WIFI network.

Four studs help to align the screen with the window and prevent the screen to touch the Wemos module.

The lid slides between small studs and clicks into the back of the case to remain in place. You may need a small screw driver to open it.

You'll find sample code in the files list which displays an Hello World message (like the one you see on photos).

All my work on Thingiverse comes with source files (not just STLs), you should do like me to make remixes easier for everyone :)

I used following softwares :

  • FreeCAD for 3D modeling
  • Cura for slicing
  • Fritzing : for wiring schematics
  • Arduino IDE : for writing hello-world example and flashing the D1 mini
    for wiring schematics I used Fritzing and https://github.com/mcauser/Fritzing-Part-WeMos-D1-Mini

To check if everything would fit well before printing, I made two mockups available on Thingiverse :

  • OLED screen
  • Wemos D1 Mini

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.06mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I used red PLA with following temperatures :

  • heatbed : 70°C
  • extruder : 200°C

Printer speeds :

  • print : 60mm/s
  • travels : 120mm/s

I made two mockups (as stated in the description) then modeled the case using those mockups to check everything can fit.

The first version had a too large screen window, studs were not large enough to maintain the lid and the USB port was not centered.

All this issues are fixed on this second version, posted on Thingiverse.

I needed to dry the inside of a small hose that is part of a drinking system for tracking and outdoor sports. The cone shaped extension for a standard PC fan should compress the fans airflow to a small diameter. The top nozzle has the same diameter as the hose and can be directly attached to it.

The desing makes use of the parametric approach of OpenSCAD.
In my case, a fan of 70 mm width and height was used.
The bottom side of the fan is protected with a grille.
Use 4 screws M4 x 30 to assemble the stack of grille, fan and compressor cone.

The magnet can be stored now ready to use. see photos.

Enjoy !

title: Power supply isolator for metal frames

description.text:
This part was designed to solve an issue about power isolation from the power supply to all electronics and motors connected on metal frames.

Print both external and internal parts for each screw that you need to use to fix the power supply. Drill your frame using 7mm drill and put the internal part inside the external one.

Recomended use a washer on screews only on internal side.

After use, we get 3.5mm distance from the back of power supply and the frame.

description.text:
A speaker mount for a horizontal alignment of 2 logitech speakers from a 5.1 set. One holder combines a front and a rear speaker and rises them approximately 2.3cm over ground.
The slim horizontal design of te mount allows placing the spekers under the displays of a multi monitor setup.
The mount uses the original screws, so that nothing than the printed mount is needed.
I printed with 2.4mm layerheight, however a lower one would produce nicer results (or just sand them afterwards).
With the 25% infill and the 3 wall lines I used, the mount is not super stable, but strong enough to hold the speakers with ease.

description.text:
50mm to 25mm Spool Adapter

This is an adapter to make M3d Pro Spools work better on the Hatch Box spool holder (or any spool holder with a ~25mm dowel). This moves the center of mass closer to the middle to reduce the force required to pull the filament into the printer.

I have included the archive Fusion 360 file incase you need to make changes. The parts shown here are the bodies named "Main Part" and "Nut".

title: Better Y axis for flsun cube with belt tensioner

description.text:
Y-axis, pulley side and stepper carriages with integrated belt tensioner. Pulley side is basically a mirror image of the stepper side. This design adds around 20mm to Y, X and Z.

Note that distance between linear shafts is 70mm (not standard). It's wider so hot end can be mounted in between the rails for better stability. You'll need to design your own hot end mount for the X axis.

Parts needed:

transplanted from the cube:
-two 400mm shafts
-4 8mm linear bearings (mounted using single zip tie each)
-stepper motor/16t pulley
Z-stop
X-stop
Z-stop

new parts:
-M3 screws (I'm using 10mm M3 screws that screw directly into plastic but eventually, as plastic wears out holes I expect to use long screw with a nut as designed). Probably one screw per shaft is plenty but there's provision for two.
-belt tensioner screw needs to be at least 25mm long
-new belt may be needed if you cut your original belts short...
-It would be best to use stepper anti vibration damper to isolate hot stepper from plastic, I suppose standoffs or washers would also be fine
16t gt2 pulley for X-axis to replace 20t smooth pulley that came with flsun

A lot of holes in carriages are unused, they serve to reinforce the print (when printing multiple walls little infill is needed). I had to use a drill to enlarge/smooth out holes for 8mm rods (I used a drill going in reverse to avoid it biting into the plastic)

When installing, I recommend following order:
attach linear bearings to the carriage with a zip tie ( nylon zip tie - not the brittle ones that came with the printer)
mount carriage to the Y linear rods
link carriages with one or two x axis rods
relocate Y linear rods higher to align carriages tops (where belt tensioner is) with the 16t pulleys
to install Y belts loosen all of the pulleys, tension belts, align pulleys and then screw them to Y shaft. Locking pulleys to the shaft before tensioning Y belts will result in uneven belt tension.
Relocate Y motor from outside to inside of the profile
hole in the back of the motor carriage is for access to pulley's set screw

I suggest to print single wall model first to see how it works- it prints in about 2.5 hours.

Overall, advantage to this design is lighter, more rigid and stable Y axis resulting in less 'ghosting' or 'ringing'. And, of course, less screws that will loosen over time causing headaches... Unfortunately that does not correct crooked 8mm rods that came with the printer...

Printer:

any

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

4 walls/perimeters
print two of the tensioner nut

Why

Original kit was a tedious to assemble due to many screws. Even when new, ringing was visible in parts with holes or sharp corners. New carriages remove a lot of parts, add rigidity and have build in belt tensioner.

description.text:
Since I started with 3d printing I have always bought extra parts to directly replace them when needed, however they were just laying around in plastic bags (all individually).

This case is designed to store all (or most) of your MK8 nozzles, and as an bonus I have added deeper holes to store PTFE throat’s, but also slightly deeper holes to store your special nozzles.
In the top of the case I used 1.85mm glass to be able to see all the parts, without getting dust inside. If wanted you are also able to add 3mm glass instead of the 1.85mm.

In this design there are separate compartments to store different kind of nozzle’s.
Here are the compartments as listed:
• 8 pieces, PTFE throats (Top)
• 10 pieces, 0.4mm nozzles (Middle)
• 4 pieces, 0.3mm nozzles (Bottom, left)
• 3 pieces, 0.4mm special nozzles (Bottom, middle)
Above can be used for: Stainless, hardened, E3D.
• 4 pieces, 0.2mm nozzles (Bottom, right)

The case consists out of the following parts:
• 1x Case bottom
• 1x Drawer
• 2x Hinge top
• 1x Case top V2.0
• 4x Friction holder glass
• 1x Glass 1.85mm (Optional)

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

20

Notes:

Printed with an 0.4mm nozzle and metallic grey + green PLA filament.

This case is designed to easily print, assemble and replace (if needed).
There is no support or extra layer adhesion needed to print all of the components, for the ‘Hinge top’ it is recommended to use support but it is not needed.
All of the parts were printed at 20% infill, except for the ‘Drawer’ there I used 12% because 20% would be too much and take allot longer to print.

My printer has an slight deviation when it comes to angled corners, because the 'Case top' was printed on the other side and flipped to fit the case. That's why the top is not perfectly symmetrical compared to the ‘Case bottom’.

To assemble the nozzle storage case there are not a lot of steps required but I will explain it below. It is important to first assemble the ‘Hinge top’ and the ‘Case bottom’ before pressing them in the ‘Case top V2.0’, if not there is no flex between the 2 arms of the hinge and they will break off.

  1. Take the glass and ‘Case top V2.0’ and put the glass inside.
  2. Apply the 4 ‘Friction holder glass’ at the corners, it is recommended to use needle nose pliers to firmly push them in place.
  3. Take the ‘Hinge top’ and press the arms of the hinge a little bit together, now push them inside of the arms from ‘Case bottom’.
  4. Repeat step 3 with the second ‘Hinge top’ at the other hinge location.
  5. Press the 4 holes of ‘Case top V2.0’ on the 4 pins of the 2 ‘Hinge top’
  6. Let the ‘Drawer’ slide in the ‘Case bottom’ and give an light push to remove the remaining air beneath the ‘Drawer’.
  7. Place all your nozzles and throats inside.
  8. Enjoy!

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
This is a modular rack system to hold four Raspberry Pi 3s along with a network switch, USB power hub, and a fan. Builds as a set of modules, which clip together to form a full system.

The devices I used are:

  • Netgear ProSAFE 5-port gigabit switch - UK part number GS105UK
  • RAVPower 60W mains charger - UK part number UK RP-PC028(B)
  • USB 5V-powered 80mm x 80mm x 25mm fan (sourced through Ebay)

and of course a bunch of Raspberry Pis!

To avoid excessive height, I used a right-angled figure-8 power connector for the USB power block.

BTW the video in the gallery is one of Vi Hart's excellent explanations why Tau is better than Pi. Go follow her!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

"Fast"

Notes:

Used Wanhao "fast" print setting (0.15mm layer depth, 0.5mm line width) - total about 48 hours of print time for all components.

Used brim to prevent corners lifting during print; the 4-Pi module is particularly susceptible so watch out for that. Enclosing the printer helps here to reduce temperature fluctuations and draughts.

Supports are used mostly for the "beams" at the back of the system. Mostly the supports are easily removed; poke through the diamond wall holes to break off the support panels internal to the modules. Grid support type gave most consistent results.

Additional - the fan retaining beam posts are weak if oriented flat on the build plate, hence what looks like an odd orientation for it in the .stl presented here (which need a little support as a result). Take a look at dbgeorge's make for a remix of that piece with a neat alternative solution to the post strength problem (and a nice Raspberry front panel!).

Designed in OpenSCAD, the main source is of course the cr.scad file. This file can generate all of the STL modules - refer to the comments at the top of that file to see how to use it, but essentially you render the same design separately for each module by changing a variable assignment towards the top of the file.

The name plate is presented here as two separate prints (the plate, and the words), which can be glued together - they have sufficient tolerance that they fit neatly. However there is also a variant for use with multi-extruder printers that can be generated without the tolerance. My printer has a single extruder, so printing like this means all the fun of swapping filament mid-layer - hence the depth of the words is reduced to minimise the number of filament swaps.

"Two Tau"? Well, pi is wrong so here I have two tau's worth of Raspberry Pis.

Modifying the name plate is left as an exercise for those (wrong :) ) people who prefer to use the half-a-circle constant...

title: Mr Freeze Ice Maker Water Seal Nut

description.text:
This is a replacement sealing nut for a Mr. Freeze Ice Maker. It also works with MaxiMatic and other brands manufactured by Mr. Freeze.

It's a tricky part to find because it has a nonstandard thread diameter (11.6mm), and it's reverse-threaded (you turn counterclockwise to tighten, and clockwise to loosen).

If you print this part, please leave a comment with your ice maker model and whether or not it worked, so that others will have more information. My ice maker is a MaxiMatic MIM-88, and it fits perfectly.

title: Samsung Galaxy S8 Case with Solar Sytem

description.text:
This is a smartphone case for the Samsung Galaxy S8 with the Solar System on the back. The planet and sun diameters are drawn to scale, though Saturn's rings are somewhat flattened to keep the case functional. The planets can be printed in a different color for contrast and then glued on.

Another option, if you prefer to keep a flat case, is to just print the body and omit the planets. The case looks great with just the the silhouettes as well.

For printing the case, I'd recommend a filament that's somewhat flexible, otherwise it could break while fitting it onto the phone. ABS or some PLA's work good. I did not give the holes for the planets any margin, so it might take some filing to make it fit, but I preferred that over the chance it would be too loose.

description.text: This object has been developed as part of the art project "Whisper Down The Lane", currently being developed by Bronwyn Holloway-Smith in conjunction with the exhibition The Obstinate Object: Contemporary New Zealand Sculpture at City Gallery Wellington, New Zealand (24 February -? 10 June 2012). During the exhibition digital 3D models will be made of selected works in The Obstinate Object in collaboration with designers Ant Pelosi and Nick Graham. The files for these models will be released for free download on Thingiverse under a Creative Commons BY-SA-NC License. Each physical work in this series is also available for purchase through a manufacture-on-demand system. The models are being produced in New Zealand using the Open Source RepRap 3D printer (with Vik Olliver). Order editions on the project webpage: http://bronwyn.co.nz/projects/whisper-down-the-lane The project will start with one work and will then gradually grow over the course of the exhibition as new works are completed and released. To receive notifications of new releases follow @hollowaysmith on Twitter, or join the mailing list at http://bronwyn.co.nz/contact/ Update 16 August 2013: The working files for the arm, body, hood, and the actual layout we printed from have now been uploaded all zipped up in a .tgz folder for your convenience :)

description.text:
SO this was sorta of necessity and one of the reasons I love 3D printing. I sorta misjudged the depth of my lack enclosure and my 13 mm Plexiglas surrounds caused the door not to shut. If I pushed the printer back far enough for the door to shut the bed hit the back wall before it met the end stop. I know, I know I should have measured twice and cut once so to say but hindsight being 20/20 I had to adapt.

So.... I made these offset hinges to "push the door out the thickness of the Plexiglas. These need to be strong if you print them and have thick ass Plexiglas as I did.\

*** This is only for right swing/side hinges, I did not draw any of these for the left side. The pin orientation is what makes them left and right sided due to the lift off ability. Tight tolerances since I wanted them to be strong.

title: Plantygon - Modular Geometric Stacking Planter for Succulents

description.text:
Plantygon is a modular geometric stacking planter. Designed to accommodate my growing collection of succulents, it is based on the truncated octohedron which can tesselate in 3D space. This allows each planter to stack together in any combination that you’d like!

Each planter has a sloped inner drain leading to holes which drain into the neighboring planters. A version without drainage holes is also available for indoor use.

Printed planters available on Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/PrintFutura

Print more to build your garden as your succulents propagate, or collect many varieties of tiny plants!

Designed in Autodesk Fusion 360 on macbook, and printed on Ultimaker 2+ at 0.15 mm layer height.

Supports optional depending on your printer’s bridging ability, I print in Cura with supports set to ‘Touching Buildplate’.

Updated files with improved printability now available! I reworked the inner surfaces and made some other small tweaks to improve the print quality of the top half of the part.

description.text:
I wanted to re-use the PSU from a Tevo Tarantula on a new Hypercube, unfortunately the S-300-12 PSU is nothing like the supply in the BOM.

This is similar to the original design but moves the switch to the outside of the printer and has the correct mounting holes for my PSU. As there are only usable holes on one side of the supply I have used a thin back plate to hold it a bit tighter - there is some play but nothing serious.

To fit it together I tapped the switch holes to accept M3 fittings and the holes on the side of the PSU to M5.

description.text:
**Update (7/24/2017): Important notes in the print settings.

I've been debating mounting a TV on the ceiling above my bed. The only reason I haven't done it is because of a fear of being crushed by a falling TV while I'm sleeping.

This design allows me to watch Youtube, Netflix, or other streaming video while I'm falling asleep.

Non-Printed Parts:
Adhesive Metal Plate for Magnetic Phone Mounts
4-Pack Enkay 4480-C Magnets
4x Screws that fit in a 5 mm hole with a head diameter no larger than 7.9 mm
4x Wall Anchors for those screws
Electrical Tape

If I had to guess on the screw size based on the charts I found online, I would say it's a #10 screw, but I designed the wall mount around some unlabeled screws and anchors I had lying around.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Highly Recommended Settings: Keep parts oriented as I've set them. Some parts will require support. The reasoning is that, when printed on my printer at 20%, there was a consistent weak spot at the base of the threading. If you want to print without supports, you can reorient those parts in your slicer and print at a higher infill, maybe 50%.

Infill: 20%
Wall Width: 1.2 mm
Top Thickness: 1.2 mm

Also, for parts that have to fit together, I highly recommend using one printer to print all the parts. I have found that one of my printers prints marginally larger (0.1-0.2 mm/20 mm), and on larger pieces, the tolerances will be off enough that the pieces will not fit right.

Magnets

The bottom layers on both of my printers tend to screw with the tolerances. I had to scrape the rims of the holes for the magnets before they would pop in, essentially widening the diameters for the first couple of layers.

Magnetic Mount Cap

The electrical tape provides a higher-friction surface than the plastic provides. Place a few strips across the surface of the cap that the phone will sit on, and this helps to prevent the phone from sliding.

Make sure the cap is screwed down firmly to minimize the distance from the adhesive metal plate on the back of your phone and the magnets.

description.text:
This is a small piece to hold up your laptop if it gets hot just sitting on the table. I created this because I was tired of using random things like batteries to prop it up. You will ideally want to print four of these and put them at the corners to lift your computer a couple centimeters and allow some airflow.

Be careful when removing the square stand from your printer, as the sharp edges may damage the print surface of your printer. (Shouldn't do anything to a glass bed, but may damage kapton tape, buildtak, painter's tape, or similar.)

Printer:

XYZPrinting Da Vinci Jr. 1.0

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

At least 15%

Notes:

DO NOT use thin shells for this design. Also, ignore my printer model. It's really garbage, I'm sure your printer is sufficient.

My daughter wanted to learn to play Checkers but we didn't have a set in the house, so I designed these in TinkerCAD. Obviously you only need two designs for a full set (like Rebels and Empire) but I thought I would give some other options as well. Just pick two designs and print 12 of each piece. I printed these at 0.15 layer height since the pieces are slightly curved on the top and bottom, but you can try printing one piece on your printer to see how things go.

height = 150

container_bottom_thick = -1

diameter = 100

divider_wall_thickness = -1

description.text:
Sometimes the (not original) power / data cable tends to wiggle a bit from left to right. To protect the female part of the plug you just have to enlarge the contact area of the cable. This could be done by using the provided tool.

The fit is very tight so you have to press hard until the plug clicks into the cut outs inside of the protector. After that everything should be fine.

Unless I'm not using the original but to different cables I've provided two Fusion 360 files. If your plug has other dimensions you can edit the parameters on your own or change the layout of the plug. Cut outs should be transfered automaticaly.

Factory files are for my Prusa MKS2 and ridget inc PLA.
